Award.AwardTitle: Low Dimensional Cohomology and the Geometry of Hilbert Space
Award.AbstractNarration:
Property (T), which states that every isometric action of a group on Hilbert space has a fixed point, is an indispensable tool in the study of rigidity. Isometric actions on Hilbert space can be described in the language of low-dimensional cohomology with coefficients in a unitary representation. A result of Chatterji-Drutu-Haglund shows that median space actions are sufficiently rich to embody the theory of isometric actions on Hilbert space. Through this proposal, the PI will expand on recent collaborations and look at the connections between isometric Hilbert space actions and actions on median spaces via the tool of low dimensional cohomology.

Newton affirmed that the universe "looks the same in every direction." This cosmological principle leads to the conclusion that the large scale geometry of the universe must be spherical (absence of parallel lines), Euclidean (uniqueness of parallel lines), or hyperbolic (existence and non-uniqueness of parallel lines). These geometries can only be understood in the large scale since Einstein's theory of general relativity asserts that masses locally distort the space-time fabric. Understanding the study of large scale geometry and symmetry was revolutionized by Gromov's approach to group theory. A group is the collection of symmetries of an object. The PI's research is concerned with CAT(0) geometry, a mix between Euclidean and hyperbolic geometries. More specifically, she studies rigidity, which can be thought to address the questions: 1) Can a group be represented as a collection of symmetries of a certain geometric object? 2) If so, is such a representation unique? The study of rigidity is important in its own right as a mathematical phenomenon. Nevertheless, it could one day lead to a better understanding of our universe.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project endeavors to further the study of infinite groups from a geometric and analytic perspective. A group is the collection of symmetries of an object. (For example, one may consider the group of translations of the Euclidean plane, and this should be keept in mind as an example for what will be said below.) In the 1980's Gromov turned this concept in on itself by asking us to consider the object in question to be the group itself. This paradigm shift revolutionized how infinite groups were perceived thereby opening up the use of geometric and analytic tools. These tools allow one to measure distances, and analyze infinite processes, respectively. 

There are three types of (homogeneous) geometries: spherical (absence of parallel lines), Euclidean (uniqueness of parallel lines), or hyperbolic (existence and non-uniqueness of parallel lines). The PI focuses her research on CAT(0) geometry which is a mix of Euclidean and hyperbolic geometry. A special subclass of such spaces are CAT(0) cube complexes which arise by gluing unit Euclidean cubes, isometrically along their faces, in a "non-spherical" way. These beautiful geometric spaces, thanks to their simplicial CAT(0) structure, have deep connections to analytic properties of the groups acting on them. 

The PI, both individually and with her collaborators, studied groups of symmetries of CAT(0) cube complexes and infinite processes on them, such as random walks. A random walk can be described as follows: if one is standing on a street corner, one may roll some dice to determine which near-by street corner to walk to, and then repeat this process indefinitely. Random walks are discrete versions of the empirically observed physical phenomenon of Brownian motion.  A key result from this project came by studying the connection between random walks and symmetries of CAT(0) cube complexes. The PI and her collaborators were able to deduce that groups of symmetries of CAT(0) cube complexes (under nonelementary-type assumptions) always contain "regular elements". Several of her results helped towards this conclusion, and this is a great step toward understanding what kinds of behavior are exhibited by these groups of symmetries. Regular elements are symmetries that decompose into "rank-1" factors. The existence of rank-1 elements has already established itself as a significant tool in the understanding of the geometric and analytic properties of the groups that contain them. With the existence of regular elements, one can (and hope to) greatly generalize the knowlege available for rank-1 elements to the cases where regular elements exist. (In the "reducible" case, it is known that rank-1 elements can not appear, but regualar elements may.)

Additionally because of this award the PI and her collaborators were able to travel and therefore meet in person and/or travel to various institutions and conferences both domestically and internationally to share their work and collaborate on solving cutting edge problems. Sustained face-to-face interactions are crucial. Indeed, in a unique way, they provide the opportunity for people with a variety of expertise to combine their knowledge into ground breaking work. In particular, thanks to this grant, the PI was able to be in full residence at the trimester program on "Random Walks and the Asymptotic Behavior of Groups" at the Henry Poincare Institute, housed in Paris, France. There she established important collaborations and gained crucial insights, through conversations and lectures, that lead to these results. Also, thanks in part to this grant, the PI ran a general audience lecture series which aspired to educate the local audience about fascinating topics in math, statistics, and physics.
